events.target_title: monitors.xml not parsed or applied after reboot with multiple monitors in non-default positions

note.body:
Merging gdm#474 with this as it appears to be a mutter bug and not GDM:


monitors.xml is not parsed or applied correctly during login after reboot or shutdown

WORKAROUND

Replace gdm3 with slick-greeter + lightdm-settings + gnome-screensaver + numlockx(optionally)

TL;DR

Correct positioning and working of multiple displays until reboot or shutdown and then subsequent login from gdm3. HDMI monitor(projector) goes blank and the VGA monitor only shows 'Secondary' monitor screen without any user visible controls or windows as they are all being painted to the now blanked 'Primary' HDMI connected display.

REPRODUCTION

After a clean install of Ubuntu 18.10, connecting a FHD(1920x1080) LED monitor to the VGA port of a DELL Optiplex 390 desktop tower, connecting a wireless HDMI Tx/Rx(LKV HDbitT-4K) to the HDMI port with a FHD projector and then configuring the logical monitor layout in the "Displays" settings dialog, I can successfully create and use a multi monitor setup in my current session.

However, after a reboot or power cycle of the computer and a successful login from GDM(gdm3), the HDMI goes dark(blank?) and the VGA monitor shows as 'Secondary' monitor even though I set it as 'Primary' in the "Displays" dialog.

The monitors.xml file, attached, shows the correct layout and survives the reboot without alteration.

I am unable to see anything on the 'Primary' display, which has incorrectly been given to the HDMI projector. Unseating the HDMI cable does not restore the VGA to 'Primary' display automatically and I must reboot the computer while leaving the HDMI unplugged in order to restore my ability to see the 'Primary' display on the VGA connection.

Replacing GDM(gdm3) with LightDM(slick-greeter) fixes the issue and is repeatedly provable through multiple reboots or changes to the logical layout of the screens in the 'Displays' settings of gnome-control-center.

ERRORS(syslog)

"Failed to get current display configuration state: GDBus.Error:org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.NameHasNoOwner: Name "org.gnome.Mutter.DisplayConfig" does not exist"

gnome-shell[3007]: JS ERROR: Exception in callback for signal: loaded: TypeError: monitor is null#012_prepareStartupAnimation@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/layout.js:653:17#012wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/_legacy.js:82:22#012_loadBackground/signalId<@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/layout.js:608:13#012_emit@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/signals.js:128:27#012_init/id<@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/background.js:512:17

SourcePackage: gdm3

UpgradeStatus: No upgrade log present (probably fresh install)

monitors.xml

Chris Rainey @ckrzen changed title from monitors.xml is not parsed or applied correctly after reboot or shutdown to monitors.xml is not parsed or applied correctly during login after reboot or shutdown 3 months ago

So standard deviation is the new "radius".

(offtopic: if you really want to improve the gui, then you probably need to move the filters into their own window and show animation images next to the filter name, that demonstrate what they do.
and maybe rename the categories; you could either create a new window or integrate it into the bottom of the toolbox and also show standard deviation and scaling sliders there (the filter's parameters, depending on the filter))

dumb users can only handle a sharpness filter with one parameter correctly (IMHO)

Mmh that's interesting, I didn't expect that, but I also don't use GTK very often (currently Windows, but I plan to retry installing Linux again (driver troubles in the past))

>For many option menus, the items you are most likely to want to choose are those immediately before or after the currently selected one. This is true for more menus than those where you are most likely to want to change to the first item or the last item. Therefore, the most efficient behavior for an option menu is opening it so that the currently selected item is immediately under the pointer, because that results in least mouse movement and eye movement to access the previous/next items.

events.target_title: Support a system-wide dark preference

note.body:
I don't understand why any app could not just follow the user's preferred theme setting, whether it is a light or dark or purple or whatever. Most people have a reason to prefer a certain theme. If they don't, they propably keep the distribution's default setting, which in turn should be a well-curated design by the distro vendor and not intervened by any application.

Recently it even came to mainstream to switch between light and dark themes depending on time of day or surrounding light situation. Any outlier application with an "I follow my own theming rules"-attitude will distract more than if it followed the same settings everything else on the screen does.

note.body: Don't know if you have a possibility to see into a Google account or an Android phone with Google calendar, but in the web version of the Google calendar it shows as a separate calendar called Reminders. It contains small tasks which have a start time, a reoccuring setting, a description and a possibility to hit a DONE button. Originally it replaced the Tasks functionality, but now I see Tasks are completely separate. Anyway, it might be something that Google implemented, not really a standard thing - no idea really. In an Android phone, when you open a Google calendar you have an option to create a standard Event with all its details, but then you have an option to create a Reminder, which goes into that special sub-calendar and only has those few options. When I add the Google account in Gnome using Online accounts, that Reminder sub-calendar is the only thing missing. I can see all calendars except that one.

events.target_title: WIP: Add Accessibility Overlay Colour

note.body:
When it comes to support, you are right. The fewer, the better.

Color Overlay does not interfere badly with Inverted Colors. The user can just uncheck Color Overlay & press CTRL+R restoring normality, without the need to re-open the document. It should be easy to patch Color Overlay to be ignored IF Inverted Colors is checked (on).

Indeed, Inverted Colors is very hard on the eyes. Impaired users are known to see "the letters jump out of the pages" when high contrast colours were used: white-on-black, but also, black-on-white.

So, how do we do it?

[**Research**](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~jbigham/pubs/pdfs/2017/colors.pdf) has already shown the way to fix this. Backgrounds with specific colours will help MASSIVELY improve reading easiness. Three colour as a background seem to work well:

Peach = #EDD1B0 (default in "Color Overlay" feature), Orange = #EDDD6E, Yellow = #F8FD89 

If it would be possible to use only CSS that would be amazing. There was an Evince [commit](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evince/commit/dbc67b85fa737fa9a66c4bc7b4c30e82be9c8543) that said that the default system theme CSS causes problems with the background.

When tested setting a specific or even a system-wide Evince CSS didn't couldn't produce the desired effect. The CSS inside Evince's libdocument seems to be overridden most likely by the document backends.

What about patching all the backends - poppler's PDF, DJVU, XPS. Even if patched, which is very difficult, long, and won't always work perfect, images in documents tend to be on top layers. That means a white image will still be very problematic for the reader. Scanned pdf books, documents, and forms are typically mostly white, so it doesn't make much sense to patch the backends.

Color Overlays BYPASSES ALL of THAT, by acting on the top layer, non-destructively.

In every case. Lets get it done - however we do it! Lets get people reading!

events.target_title: WIP: Add Accessibility Overlay Colour

note.body:
Yes, impairments are not all alike, that's very true and relevant. Choosing between impairments is a bad idea, so lets fix Inverted Colors. Any general ideas?

Some suggestions, to comment on:

1. Make Color Overlay not change anything if Inverted Colors is turned on. Quick solution. Doesn't need much support afterwards.

2. Merge Inverted Colors and Color Overlay in one "theme" property feature, with it's own dialog. Then allow the user to switch between normal black-font-white-background and a custom theme option, even if such a theme will currently require some dconf schemas. Eventually to be replaced by a real CSS, once we figure out how.

login to tty

SHIFT+CTRL+F2
wait for the desktop to recover

Problem loading 16-bit grayscale TIFF
Problem loading 16-bit grayscale TIFF

note.body:
Confirmed. The problem is leftover files from GIMP 2.8.22. Rather than reinstall, I just looked at the files directly. 

GIMP 2.8.22 had plugin file-tiff-load.exe and file-tiff-save.exe, while GIMP 2.10.2 just uses file-tiff.exe . It seems that GIMP was using those older files instead of the new one. Removing them fixed the problem.

Not closing for two reasons: 

1. Is prioritizing the -save and -load plugins intended behavior, or a bug?

2. I would definitely say that not removing those files is a bug in the installer. But I don't know if installer bugs are maintained here.

events.target_title: Untranslated desktop file in Ubuntu

note.body:
While Debian and Ubuntu source code of Geary are exactly the same (compared unpacked by Meld, debian folder included) the binary packages are different:

Distro - Architecture - Package Size - Installed Size

Debian - amd64 - 1,579.6 kB - 6,813.0 kB

Ubuntu - amd64 - 1,568.1 kB - 6,775.0 kB

One of the changes is replacing of translations by `X-Ubuntu-Gettext-Domain=geary` in .desktop files (next changes are cut old entries in the changelog, higher compression of pictures and some modification of /usr/bin/geary file).

It looks like Ubuntu modifies binary packages while importing them from Debian without new changelog entry. So it is not even Geary packaging bug it is Ubuntu issue.

events.target_title: Night light should allow selecting a location to use

note.body:
To restate the use case: when geolocation is disabled in the privacy settings, night light gets the location wrong. There are the manual settings to set the time of sunset/sunrise, but because those change with the seasons, it would be better to set the location instead.

Telling people to turn geolocation on is not a solution, and hence it seems the issue is not related to geoclue, which seems to have derailed the discussion above.

Ability to search in Nautilus and sort the results by column

note.body: To add another example of real life use of this feature (which I actually do all the time with Windows): I have a lot of text files that share a common part of the name but in different folders. Many times, when I need to produce a new version of this type of text I need to look for the last version I have, to use it as a template. In that case, I need to look for files with part of the name in common and then sort by inverse date order to be able to find that last version I'm looking for.

events.target_title: pam-gnome-keyring.so reveals user’s password credential as a plaintext form Edit
pam-gnome-keyring.so reveals user’s password credential as a plaintext form Edit
pam-gnome-keyring.so reveals user’s password credential as a plaintext form Edit

note.body:
That’s correct. 

Unfortunately, however, Ubuntu Linux, including trusty (14.04LTS), xenial (16.04LTS) and artful (17.10), is still exposed to above bugs because it is not applied the patch.

Please ensure that gnome-keyring is updated to reflect the latest patch for gnome-keyring 3.18/3.20.

As I mentioned before, this raises concerns over the credential being misused for illegal behavior, such as acquiring user’s session key.

During post-exploitation, it can cause serious problems such as leak of user credentials located in gnome-keyring.

events.target_title: pam-gnome-keyring.so reveals user’s password credential as a plaintext form Edit

note.body: Okay, I'll fix it that way.

events.target_title: Credentials located in gnome-keyring can be compromised easily.
Credentials located in gnome-keyring can be compromised easily.

note.body:
They’ve had stories in the Ubuntu Security FAQ about gnome-keyring that have been untrue.
Just I’d like to check the fact properly is described.

@halfline Anyway, I don’t understand how you recognize the problem as a trivial issue. With your logic, I don’t understand why user credentials are encrypted with the key; a user can only access its keyring file (~/.local/share/keyrings/*.keyring) while others cannot without privilege escalation. It seems that many people consider the problem as a critical privacy issue. As you may know, it also has been reported about this to many Linux distributions. However, existing issues have focused primarily on the behavior of seahorse and simply expect to prompt for a password before displaying a key’s plaintext password. Instead, I would like to propose a different method by using access control scheme provided by DBus internal. 

As you mentioned before, it cannot help preventing the password-cracking since Linux doesn’t fundamentally provide app level sandboxing. Before the absence of sandboxing, however, the issue has been arising from the lack of security policy in rpc/dbus. Existing other services based on DBus are already taking advantage of this way.

For your information, a similar issue of keychain in MAC OS X and Android has been reported and already solved via adjustment of access control (see CVE-2015-5836/5835 and more).

events.target_title: Credentials located in gnome-keyring can be compromised easily.

note.body:
@halfline Though it is possible to attach gnome-keyring-daemon in gdb, it will not possible to extract its memory-layout/IPC/etc. information without privilege escalation since dumpable flag is cleared.
Thus, it is hard to access the daemon from any user-level processes, am I right?

Finally, gnome-keyring uses a private key, that will replace to user password in case of PAM, for storing login credential.
In this case, I don’t understand why are you mentioning about key encryption.
I just focused on encryption of login credentials using private key.

note.body:
Hi Michael,

i have the same behaviour on a fresh installed Xubuntu 18.04 and GIMP 2.10.0.

events.target_title: GIMP doesn't launch on Windows 10 (crash at every startup) due to font issues

note.body:
I can confirm that the GIMP crash is caused by fonts installed with LibreOffice (as suspected in duplicate issue #1726).
To identify which fonts were installed by LibreOffice, I uninstalled LibreOffice, made a list of all '*.tt?' files on my disk, reinstalled LibreOffice, made a new list of '*.tt?' files on my disk, then compared the lists.

It turned out that LibreOffice had added 172 font files to my C:\Windows\Fonts directory. I generated a batch file to move these files out of the way, ran the batch file, removed my C:\Windows\System32\FNTCACHE.DAT file, and rebooted. The FNTCACHE.DAT got recreated, but was smaller than the original one (shrank from 579,888 to 528,096 bytes)--which I considered a good sign.

And... Bingo! GIMP now runs fine--as does LibreOffice.

So, even though the crash is in GIMP, the fundamental problem appears to be in LibreOffice. In fact, even LibreOffice itself doesn't seem to understand the format of its font files, since its startup screen displayed its text messages in a rather unpleasant fixed-width font (probably as a fall-back option). Now, with its font files removed, it uses a far more normal font for its text messages.

Just for your info, I'm attaching the batch file that I generated to move the LibreOffice font files out of the way.

[Installed-Fonts-LibreOffice-Move.bat](/uploads/cf85d352475207b1c2e5c58680a6a595/Installed-Fonts-LibreOffice-Move.bat)

events.target_title: GIMP doesn't launch on Windows 10 (crash at every startup) due to font issues

note.body:
Yes, these are exactly the same 172 TTFs and 8 OTFs.

If you cannot reproduce the issue, then I guess that your Windows system recognises the LibreOffice fonts just fine?
When I open the C:/Windows/Fonts folder in Windows Explorer, the LibreOffice fonts just won't show up.

Also, when you start GIMP, I suppose that the startup screen shows you the expected text messages, and not the 'missing-character' rectangles, as it does for me?

I'll try and install GIMP and LibreOffice together on my dad's laptop one of these weekends. He uses Dutch-language settings, just as on my laptop, so if I cannot reproduce the issue there, then we can at least rule out the language settings as the culprit.

note.body:
One observation here, I think this started to happen more often since I (was forced) to sync a gmail folder.
I'm using the gmail imap interface and obviously the folder is huge (64k emails). I wonder also if the gmail tag -> Imap folder mappings could play a role. As gmail doesn't have a concept of folders, to my understanding whenever a message is placed in a folder, it receives a tag.
So when in evolution a message is marked as deleted, I think gmail in the background then applies the deleted tag. Which makes the imap interface mark it as moved to the deleted folder. So I wonder if this could cause the message list to jump.
Just  a seculation...

events.target_title: Libinsane get devices error when upgrading from 1.2.4

note.body:
https://openpaper.work/en-us/scanner_db/report/409/ 

It turns out actually scanning with ironscanner works.

This gave me a new idea: After reproducing the error once again, I went to the settings screen, and checked that the right scanner was selected. It was the case. I clicked on "preview" in this screen, and scanning worked. Then I closed the settings screen, and tried to scan a new documents, and it worked.

My analysis (which may be wrong): paperwork had some settings in memory inherited from pyinsane2. These settings were incompatible with libinsane, hence the error message. Going to the settings screen makes paperwork rediscover these settings, and the everything works.

So if there is an issue, it is only that if a scanning error happens, maybe paperwork should rediscover scanning settings ?

In any case, feel free to close the issue.

>  In fact, any letter is ok as long as it is > h (`hiberfil.sys`) and < p (`pagefile.sys`). Also you don't have to use single-letter-folders: Something like `hiberfil.sys2` works, too.

events.target_title: Preserve layer transparency while using transforming tool.
Preserve layer transparency while using transforming tool.

note.body:
I do not see that option for "Move" tool, but it does exits at other transformation tools like Resize ...
I think this option should exist in many tools.

When you have a layer with a transparency different to 100% and you select that layer for moving it, the selection gets 100% transparency while moving the layer, so you can not see background layer.

I didn't want to open an issue, this was more like an ask for new options or new features.

It also happens with not text layers.

events.target_title: Text becomes very blurry after rotating

note.body: @littlearcher I also see differences between versions 2.10.x and 2.8.x when it comes to rotating image layers. The precision when you make a rotation in 2.8 is much higher than in 2.10, where the image becomes somewhat blurry. The differences between the two versions can be seen with the naked eye.

events.target_title: FTBFS: Multiple tests fail

note.body:
To clarify my previous post, there is a **xvfb-run binary** from xvfb package, but no **xvfb-run package**:
```
# xvfb-run --help
Usage: xvfb-run [OPTION ...] COMMAND
Run COMMAND (usually an X client) in a virtual X server environment.
Options:
-a        --auto-servernum          try to get a free server number, starting at
                                    --server-num
-e FILE   --error-file=FILE         file used to store xauth errors and Xvfb
                                    output (default: /dev/null)
-f FILE   --auth-file=FILE          file used to store auth cookie
                                    (default: ./.Xauthority)
-h        --help                    display this usage message and exit
-n NUM    --server-num=NUM          server number to use (default: 99)
-l        --listen-tcp              enable TCP port listening in the X server
-p PROTO  --xauth-protocol=PROTO    X authority protocol name to use
                                    (default: xauth command's default)
-s ARGS   --server-args=ARGS        arguments (other than server number and
                                    "-nolisten tcp") to pass to the Xvfb server
                                    (default: "-screen 0 640x480x16")

```

events.target_title: FTBFS: Multiple tests fail

note.body:
As you can see from first post, the option ```-j1``` is passed to debuild which passes it to dpkg-buildpackage.

This means that there is **no multiple simultaneous jobs run during the build process**.

Some details of the build process are available [here](https://www.debian.org/doc/manuals/maint-guide/build.en.html#completebuild).

events.target_title: FTBFS: Multiple tests fail

note.body:
Sure:

- [config.log](/uploads/4c73bc4b4d1b29c79c7b1efd052605ba/config.log)
- [test-suite.log](/uploads/cd229cee44c5550f9015f46b0a2b3c56/test-suite.log)

I discover some strange errors in ```config.log```:
- gcc: error: unrecognized command line option '-V'
- gcc: error: unrecognized command line option '-qversion'; did you mean '--version'?
```
gcc --version
gcc (Ubuntu 7.3.0-24ubuntu1) 7.3.0
```
- conftest.c:10:10: fatal error: ac_nonexistent.h: No such file or directory
That missing include is not existent in the whole official ubuntu repository:
```
# apt-file search ac_nonexistent.h
# 
```

events.target_title: FTBFS: Multiple tests fail

note.body:
@schumaml 

No such errors if I perform the usual steps with fresher 2.10.2-1 sources:
```
./configure
make
make check
```
It seems it's a debian packaging issue then.

events.target_title: FTBFS: Multiple tests fail

note.body: Finally, I was able to build the packages from the same fresh sid sources (2.10.2-1) in an Ubuntu cosmic clean chroot.

GParted does not shrinking PVs below actual physical size, so not at all

note.body:
Thanks a lot for the fix. I used GParted live, the following versions are affected:
* gparted-live-0.30.0-1-amd64.iso

events.target_title: libnotify cuts off hyperlinks in notifications, breaking the links
Use Thunderbird's autoconfig ISPDB directly, not its copy
Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
I'm a Thunderbird developer and invented the autoconfig (including the ISPDB idea, and the protocol, and developed most of its implementation, and I personally created the first version of the ISPDB with the major ISPs). Thank you, Evolution developers, for implementing it as well.

The autoconfig protocol that Thunderbird uses is documented on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Thunderbird/Autoconfiguration and https://wiki.mozilla.org/Thunderbird:Autoconfiguration:ConfigFileFormat and further described informally on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Thunderbird/Autoconfiguration/FileFormat/HowTo . I've tried my best to document everything, to allow other email clients to implement it. It has become a quasi standard, as many email client implement it.

It consists of
1. a file format for config info (which Evolution uses)
2. several methods of gathering a config file and
3. a database of ISP configs (which GNOME copied).

The ISPDB is just one method of gathering a config. However, not all small providers in the world can be put into our database. We maintain only large ISPs with >0.1% of our userbase. Smaller providers like Universities are encouraged to run their own autoconfig server on autoconfig.[emaildomain]. Supporting this method will allow you to increase your support rate a little. Note that autoconfig.[emaildomain] is complementary to ISPDB and not a replacement, as e.g. autoconfig.gmail.com doesn't exist.

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
Milan Crha, we included the email address as parameter in the autoconfig.[emaildomain] request, because some setups will require a specific username that is hard to guess. For example, Exchange servers use Windows username instead of the email address - the address might be fred.flintstone@example.com, but the username is fflintstone or worst case EXAMPLE\\fflintstone. So, an autoconfig script on the provider end can transform these, either using the custom schema that they use, or even using a database, if they would like to. For example, the ISP aon.at had numeric usernames (I sure hope they accept email addresses as usernames by now, but they didn't back then when I created the ISPDB). Passing the email address allows to support such setups.

However, I think most setups don't actually need that dynamic mapping and accept email addresses or the local part of the email address as usernames. In this case, they can use the defined placeholders in the spec and return a static configuration file. However, I don't have any statistics about how many providers use autoconfig servers, and how many of them use a dynamic config. Thunderbird app doesn't send this data back to Thunderbird project servers.

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
One thing regarding HTTPS, though: Most large hosting providers must use http, not https, because they serve many customer domains. With http, you only need to set an A record and have a web server accept all autoconfig.* domains. A hosting provider cannot register SSL certs for all autoconfig.foo customer domains. So, if you use https only, you'll lose a lot of configs of hosters.

We determined that it's not a severe problem, for 4 reasons:
* Even with HTTPS only, an attacker can do a so-called downgrade attack, block all HTTPS requests, downgrading us to other vulnerable methods that we need.
   * Our last resort method is guessing the config, which relies on DNS and is vulnerable in any case. But absolutely needed for many small domains.
   * Do you use DNS SRV? Then you don't need to worry about http vs. https ;-) . DNS SRV (which Thunderbird does not support) is vulnerable to attacks as well. Only about 1% of second level domains use DNSSEC, and deployment of DNSSEC is not improving, but actually declining in the last year, see APNIC stats. 
   * Exchange autodiscover has the same problem: it defines https and http methods, and it's the http method that is actually used in practice. Typically, the http://autodiscover.example.com will redirect to https://autodiscover.hoster.com , but at that point, https is only snake oil.
* The moment of attack is very narrow, only at setup, not during normal use.
* After finding a config, we show the mail server hostnames to the end user, and ask him to approve them.
* If the mail servers do not use SSL, we warn the end user, and ask him to approve that as well.

So, after a risk analysis, we determined that forcing HTTPS does not significantly improve security, and cuts us off from a number of hosting providers,

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
(offtopic here, but quick note:)

> Lookup e-mail domain on the GNOME server

Suggestion: Just remove "GNOME " :-) , if you want to keep it short

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
> Does Evolution support DNSSEC (and DANE)?

DNSSEC is a property of the DNS resolver, in the operating system or libraries, not of the application.

Even if it's supported, it's not actually used in practice:
APNIC writes: "DNSSEC deployment is still very low (only ~1% of .com, .net and .org domains deploy DNSSEC), and that over 30% of these domains are, in fact, misconfigured"

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
I specifically took care not to leak email addresses to third parties, therefore I contact only servers in the domain that hosts the email address with the email address. (OK, yes, it's plaintext. But then again, you can choose the moment when you set up your accounts, and email addresses leak in all kinds of places, etc..)

> Thus I'd pass only an artificial email address

Note that this violates the spirit and letter of the autoconfig.[emaildomain] protocol, which allows the provider to dynamically generate configs, even do database lookups in some cases where necessary.

If you nonetheless find it better to pass a fake one, please pass evolution@[actualemaildomain] , so that server administrators can attribute all the errors that this might produce.
You would then have to replace "evolution" in the username fields with the actual local email address part on your end. It might work, IFF the provider uses a straightforward email address -> username mapping scheme. But I do not recommend it, and it's against the current spec.

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body: Maybe you already meant that, but please make sure to pass the actual, real email address domain (not the literal "@no.where"), as hosters will need the domain to know the right config. It won't be a privacy problem, because the domain is already in the autoconfig.[actualdomain] hostname that you contact.

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body: Ah, I see. Thanks for the clarification. FWIW, I used example.com due to RFC 6761 Section 6.5. We meant the same thing, alright.

@exalm 
my issue with switching is only visible when I have one display on top/above the other.

events.target_title: [BZ#739184] Scrolling in central bar should scroll from screen position instead of cursor

note.body:
I've been too busy to consentrate on this issue, but now I had time to think about it and write some code. I have a skeleton that works like this:

* If next diff/previous diff is at about the center of the screen, move to that.
* If next diff is off screen or at the top 25% of the visible text area and user scrolls down, ignore it and search down for next diff
* If previous diff is off screen or at the bottom 25% of the visible area and user scrolls up, ignore it and search up for previous diff

I was thinking if following attitude would be more simple and feel more natural to the user:
* Check if there are any diffs currently at the visible area.
* If there is, check whether currently highlighted diff is off screen.
* If it is, select first/last of the visible diffes depending if user scrolls up or down.

Any comments? I will post my code up in few days, after a little bit of more fiddling with it.

events.target_title: [BZ#739184] Scrolling in central bar should scroll from screen position instead of cursor

note.body:
Here is the code that does what I described in the first three bullet points in my last message:
* If next diff/previous diff is at about the center of the screen, move to that.
* If next diff is above the top 25% of the visible text area and user scrolls down, ignore that diff and search down for next diff until one that is below the top 25% of the screen is found.
* If previous diff below the bottom 25% of the visible area and user scrolls up, ignore that diff and search up for previous diff until one that is above the bottom 25% of the screen is found.

There is one issue: if for example user scrolls "normally" down past four diff group and then scrolls up in the center bar, Meld does not scroll back to the last diff of that four diff group, as it would feel natural. Instead it will take whatever diff `self.cursor.prev` points at.

Should I implement a logic that changes this?

Here is a merge request:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/heikkiket/meld/merge_requests/2

events.target_title: FAT flash in nonroot account shows up as locked and root-owned

note.body:
Found a prior step that's necessary (and which I've now added to the opening post as step 0.1): The problem occurs if I insert the drive before logging into my nonroot account, not if I insert after that. The problem also occurs if insertion is earlier, either before dismissing the screen saver that comes when waking from sleep or before opening the laptop lid to waken the computer forcing a BIOS admin login (the hard drive is already logged into for decryption). This was true of both USB ports. This test was with AC power but likely applies to DC power. It likely is also true for reboot or cold boot. I don't have much experience with hibernation to be worth trying that, but it's likely the same. The key seems to be that insertion is sometime before I'm in my Linux nonroot account, or, I suppose, any Linux account.

I don't know whether this was something I hadn't noticed before or if evergreening Fedora means the problem now occurs under narrower circumstances. Possibly, updates to F28, whether the Files app was updated at the same time or not at all, may have caused updates to the kernel or other software that resolved the problem, although I wouldn't know how.

I'm still running the Files app v3.28.1-stable and I keep Fedora 28 evergreen. My installation of F28 and Files is a default installation. If you're successfully running "3.28", then maybe there's a regression error in 3.28.1-stable and maybe you're not evergreening F28. My drive had the same parentage and ownership as yours. I have no custom entry in </etc/fstab>. I didn't see my flash listed in it unless it's listed nonobviously. Two 0-byte files in /dev/disk named the flash by brand and model, not by the drive name I assigned.

The folder in step 5 is the directory rendered by following step 4. (In a GUI, directories are folders and vice versa. A CLI probably doesn't know about folders.)

In terminal (an emulator), mount produced the same output for the drive emblem and the "X" emblem. Also, gio mount -l produced the same output for both emblems.

Output of the last line from mount (after replacing the username and the drive name):

`/dev/sdb1 on /run/media/USERNAME/DRIVENAME type vfat (rw,nosuid,nodev,relatime,uid=1000,gid=1000,fmask=0022,dmask=0022,codepage=437,iocharset=ascii,shortname=mixed,showexec,utf8,flush,errors=remount-ro,uhelper=udisks2)`

Output of the last lines from gio mount -l (line breaks represented by "=====" or longer to include leading spaces because this topic does not render the line breaks) (after replacing the username and the drive name):

`Drive(2): Kingston DataTraveler G3`

`  Type: GProxyDrive (GProxyVolumeMonitorUDisks2)`

`  Volume(0): DRIVENAME`

`    Type: GProxyVolume (GProxyVolumeMonitorUDisks2)`

`    Mount(0): DRIVENAME -> file:///run/media/USERNAME/DRIVENAME`

`      Type: GProxyMount (GProxyVolumeMonitorUDisks2)`

The original gio output was rendered in terminal with no lines skipped and with the following leading spaces (if not preserved here): 0, 2, 2, 4, 4, and 6 spaces, respectively.

Here's something that happens intermittently: Unmounting, quitting the Files app, opening the Files app, and then inserting the drive sometimes produced the "X" emblem with root ownership, but I haven't figured out why the intermittency. I just did the maneuver several times with variations without a problem but had the problem a day or two ago with no cold or warm reboot in between.

If you still have difficulty replicating, I can speculate that there could be a hardware difference (including in BIOS) having to do with drive detection or that there could be a difference in how VFAT drives are formatted because maybe one bit differs affecting the Files app's behavior, but I don't know what to look for to address those possibilities.

My Dell Latitude E6400 laptop, bought refurbished and working I think a couple of years and not shared, is home to F28.

It seems version 3.30 is now out. I don't want to install it until Fedora supplies it with a Fedora update. If that happens and if the problem is fixed in there, great.

If you need more information, let me know. But if the Needs Information label can be deleted, go ahead; I don't seem to have the permission to do so.

events.target_title: search for text NOC fails to list files
GtkTextView: Problems with very long lines.

note.body:
A line length of 2048 (unless it's 2047) is the length that immediately crashes gedit 3.30.2. I found that by experimentation. I had a line length at 6069 before experimenting. The file, which is *.txt (and is text), also froze LibreOffice Writer but that may be unrelated.

It may be that clicking in the line is prerequisite for a crash to follow. If not, something is prerequisite, since I discovered I've had too-long lines in a certain file for years without a problem even though I edit the file almost daily, but it's >2MiB, I haven't edited much of it in years, and I created or added parts of it in other apps and app versions.

I suggest adding into gedit's documentation the length limit, or at least a statement of ambiguity. I was going to propose a fix to gedit itself but evidently, after 15 years since someone else's bug report, repairing it is too difficult. Nonetheless, putting it into Help would be informative.

kwrite 18.08.1 on the same platform handles it with a message and options for letting us use the file (read-only or read-write). The existence of the message implies the presence of a test, which might be considered for gedit, even if a post-test delayable exit is still the only option. Tests that may be user-usable in a terminal and perhaps may be adaptable for consideration for use inside gedit (I'm not an expert on this) are offered here: https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/42898/find-any-lines-exceeding-a-certain-length

My platform is Fedora 29 Linux, kept evergreen, on a laptop with an Intel Core 2 Duo CPU (I don't remember what general architecture that uses).

events.target_title: Request UAL video recording

note.body: @olea I also would like to help record some of the sessions. I've previously helped out with the video recording and editing at last years Manchester GUADEC. :)

events.target_title: Request UAL video recording

note.body:
/me wonders how prepared we are to record video just a few days before the event!

@olea may I make a suggestion as to what you'll need:

* At least 2 x 32GB SD cards for each of those cameras. Maybe one extra in case of failures.
* The cameras won't work with anything bigger than 32GB SDs.
* The laptops don't have to be very powerful, just have a lot of storage attached, e.g. 2TB per laptop
* I'm making the assumption that we'll be rotating SD cards between sessions.
* During each session, one SD will be in the camera recording and the other would be having the previous session's video files copied to either the laptop's HDD or an external large HDD. Last year, I had this process scripted to reduce chance of human error.
* Please take a look at @sthursfield's post above which gives a run down of the equipment we used and the procedure we had in place.

Of course, this is only a suggestion based on our experience last year. If you have much of this planned already then that's fine :) Just let us know where and how we could help in any way :)

events.target_title: Request UAL video recording

note.body:
@olea to clarify:

* Per room to be recorded:
  - 1 x camera
  - 2 or 3 32GB SD cards
  - 1 x laptop
  - 1 x 2TB external HDD

What we also did at the end of each conference day, was to copy (with rsync) all videos from room-1 HDD to room-2 HDD and vice versa, so we had a daily backup in case the worst happens. One of them HDDs then stayed at the conference centre and the other was taken off-site and returned the next morning.

events.target_title: Using Wacom Intuos 5 with libinput makes the Input Controller in GIMP perform twice
Using Wacom Intuos 5 with libinput makes the Input Controller in GIMP perform twice

note.body:
@mitch

I'm not a very good coder, but I had a look. First of all, if I select "Dump events from this controller" here's what I get:

```
linux_input_read_event: EV_ABS code = 0x28 (value = 0)
linux_input_read_event: EV_KEY code = 0x103
Received 'Wacom Intuos5 touch M Pad' (class 'Linux Input')
    controller event 'button-3 (Button 3)'
    (trigger event)
    maps to action 'edit-undo'
    action was found

linux_input_read_event: EV_ABS code = 0x28 (value = 15)
linux_input_read_event: EV_KEY code = 0x103
Received 'Wacom Intuos5 touch M Pad' (class 'Linux Input')
    controller event 'button-3 (Button 3)'
    (trigger event)
    maps to action 'edit-undo'
    action was found
```

As you can see, the event EV_ABS and EV_KEY happens twice. One says it has a value of 0 and a value of 15 (I don't know what this means, but it might be a clue to the problem), and there is no EV_REL event, even though when I use `libinput debug-events` I get this:

```
-event16  TABLET_PAD_BUTTON  +8.43s       3 pressed (mode 0)
 event16  TABLET_PAD_BUTTON  +8.68s       3 released (mode 0)
```

So press and release is programmed correctly in libinput. So it seems like the problem lies in how the `linux_input_read_event` function handles events. Maybe this documentation will help for anyone who knows how to program these events?

https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/index.html

events.target_title: Singleton objects support (patch included)
Singleton objects support (patch included)
Singleton objects support (patch included)

note.body:
@Al Tomas

You also missed one really important fact. Why Singletons even exist... because of poor reality ;)

If static classes in other languages would be any better, singletons would never be a thing at all. Problems with static classes are following

- you can't pass its reference to methods

- content is not active and as such you cannot make for example in C# NotifyPropertyChanged compliant static class

- you cannot derive them from other classes

- you cannot implement interfaces

That is the reason why Singletons are a thing. To make excuse for language not having better static class. And due to those facts, there are also whole lot of complaints.

Now, look at Vala. Vala doesn't have static class at all. Sure, you can do some tricks and implement something like

```vala
namespace MyWouldBeStaticClass
{
      public static ....
}
```

but this is sadly even poorer solution than static classes in other languages.

My implementation does two things. Removes the need for static class altogether and more importantly implements Singleton exactly how people are trying to achieve with all those poor factory attempts.

- you can pass its reference to functions, more so... you can pass even the type as any method can just create it and get to that same data

- you can control recreation by references

- content is active

- you can derive it from type

- you can implement interfaces

- best thing, it removes the need for factory instantiation method altogether. You just go with regular as always creation with new. No need to know if someone used get_instance(), get_default(), create() or ... You just recreate that object and you access it

This implementation is actually exactly what people hoped Singletons would be, but they never really could achieve that because language hides internal object construction from them.

The good question is why would anyone want to repeat known bad situation when you can make it better. Same as interfaces in Vala. Interfaces in Vala go beyond any scope of what interfaces for other languages define and don't restrict scope to what other people think... this is also reason why interfaces in Vala are far superior than interfaces elsewhere

events.target_title: GObject, construct{}, public/private ClassName() inconsistancies
GObject, construct{}, public/private ClassName() inconsistancies

note.body:
@Al Thomas

Since parameter-less constructor cannot posses any additional data it is probably fair to say it is basic class construction that fits the second link perfectly.

Reading your comment and those links I gather that best (and easiest to implement probably) would be the one I put as one of possible solutions

- if construct {} is not present, create one with empty body (ricotz already did that for Singleton patch and all that would need is expanding it to every GObject derived class)

- if MyClass() is present, append code to construct {} and make MyClass() blank which will do exactly what that link suggest, Vala objects will be consistently created

The only cave-eat that I am not sure here is if moving contents from constructor to _construct wouldn't break debugging somehow. Sadly, I don't use debuggers at all. No clue there, all I can say is that everything that I use would be completely unaffected by that change.

This change also doesn't require any warnings. Only questionable classes for that would be classes that have no construct {} and only constructors with additional parameters. Good warning would probably be something like `Creation of class XYZ cannot be verified properly, make sure class does not break if created by Object.new (typeof(XYZ))` and maybe even include some link on what this means and how Gtk deals with construction

This would also fix the classes for everyone that took C#/Java way for guaranteed and didn't check how Gtk does. All it would be needed is recompile and their classes are fixed

events.target_title: GObject, construct{}, public/private ClassName() inconsistancies

note.body:
@Rico Tzschichholz

Topic is GObject only, I don't think I could be more specific out that than I was. construct {} error reporting on non GObject is already proper action

This is completely wrong `The construct block is a common initialisation step which is executed after all constructors.` Construct block is run first then initializers line new MyClass(). You need allocated memory by Gtk

Wrong again. `This behaviour needs to be taken into account by developers themselves while constructors can contain arbitrary preparations which might be incompatible to each other.` You cannot access any property yet as it has not yet been initialized.

I made a test case here. I also added output at the end of it so you don't need to run it

events.target_title: Allow suspend with external monitor connected

note.body:
FWIW I also find this a problem. I often use my laptop with an external monitor *and* an external keyboard + mouse, and I use the laptop screen as a secondary screen. I shut the laptop when I'm done for the day and I'd like that to put it to sleep. Thoughts:
1.  It's not a huge deal, I can alt-click the shutdown button instead - but it's force of habit for me because I'm so used to doing it this way without the monitor attached
2. This behaviour would be extremely undesirable for people who need clamshell mode - which I imagine is the majority case
3. Forcing one behaviour or the other based on a potentially unreliable detection mechanism seems like a **really** bad idea

My preferred solution would definitely be a configuration option - whether or not fully exposed through the settings/tweaks - that allowed lid switch behaviour to be customised. I think the default should be to suspend unless an external monitor is attached (as currently). I'm not sure I see the value in holding this issue hostage to a fiddly and potentially unreliable input detection mechanism when a setting would solve the problem for the majority of people. 

For those that really cannot live without an automatic adjustment of the behaviour based on the presence of an external keyboard, is that not something that could be accomplished by some sort of external script/shell extension that could simply flip the LidSwitchSuspendWithExternalMonitor setting (or however it is implemented) if an external keyboard is detected?

note.body: I do, but it keeps breaking for me due to: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/tracker/issues/84 . I guess this may be the problem. I'll retest when the fix for that issue makes it into a release and let you know if the issue goes away.
